stream_context.summary: Kaze returns to Twitch via Restream (multistream to YouTube + Twitch) and continues RTYI development. He demos recent progress (expanded surface/footstep system; large outdoor area) and focuses on building the Smash 64 “Board the Platforms” retro sub-area: iterating on the iconic blue void background, solving transparency/performance concerns, implementing multi-layer background rotation via Fast64 geo nodes + custom geo ASM, and rough-blocking early platform layouts. He also discusses remaining world-theme ideas, camera-feel tweaks, and notes broken stream alerts after missing a large donation.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete engine/level-tech decisions (surface system, background rendering/perf constraints, geo-rotation implementation), roadmap reveals (remaining themes + retro-level lineup), and personal/team context (multistream return, moved houses, full-time job, missed €200 donation due to broken alerts).

findings.summary: RTYI now supports 16+ distinct floor/surface types (e.g., grass, water, stone, snow, sand, ice, mud, steel, glass, grates), implemented as per-surface flag sets that drive behaviors like footstep sounds and surface interactions.
findings.quote: Every surface has a type that is a bunch of different flags on what should be active on it.

findings.summary: Kaze shows an in-progress “Oily Boily Bay” area and emphasizes large-scale outdoor traversal, including sand that visually deforms with step patterns.
Badub has already delivered music for multiple areas Kaze is showing/working on; Kaze describes the tracks as consistently strong and uses them as a development motivator.
findings.quote: We already have songs for all these areas from Badub. And the songs are a banger.

findings.summary: Retro sub-areas are a core structural pillar: each of the 15 main courses includes a dedicated retro-inspired segment based on pre‑N64 or N64-era games; the current retro segment in progress is Smash 64’s “Board the Platforms” translated into 3D.
findings.quote: In Return to Yoshi’s Island every course out of the 15 main courses has a retro bit section.

findings.summary: Kaze lays out the remaining retro inspirations in the pipeline: next retro level after Smash 64 is planned as Mario Paint, then Dr. Mario, then Mario Land 1; he also mentions a planned Paper Mario retro level.

Performance constraints strongly shape visual design: Kaze rejects a multi-layer scrolling-texture approach for the Smash background because repeated full-screen overdraw would be too expensive on N64-era rendering constraints.
findings.quote: One time overdrawing the entire screen is like 5 milliseconds… so all four together is like 20 milliseconds.

findings.summary: After an initial attempt with many semi-transparent 3D squares distributed in space, Kaze pivots to a different method: a large UV skysphere with “Tetris-like” cutout shapes/textures to emulate Smash 64’s background more efficiently and consistently.
findings.quote: We will make a UV sphere… We’re just gonna draw the squares onto here.

findings.summary: Kaze implements multi-layer background rotation using Fast64-exported geo rotation nodes plus a custom geo ASM to drive parameters (speed/direction), then debugs incorrect rotation direction caused by order-of-operations/bitwise logic mistakes.
findings.quote: It was just the order of operations, god damn it.

findings.summary: He identifies a visual bug likely caused by a lava bubble spawning inside a pipe and another issue traced to undefined vertices in bubble code, describing it as an easy fix once found.
findings.quote: It seems that these use some undefined vertices… that was an easy bug to fix.

findings.summary: Kaze flags potential memory pressure in the level while investigating the pipe/lava-bubble artifact, implying ongoing memory-footprint management during course building.
findings.quote: We might be running low on memory in this level.

findings.summary: He discusses level-flow readability: rejects an idea involving stacked rooms connected by a rope because it could mislead players into thinking a fall is intended progression, even if technically feasible with room culling/visibility boxes.
findings.quote: I feel like that would ruin gameplay… you’re gonna be… platforming and then just falling down here because you think this is somewhere to go.

findings.summary: Kaze reveals four remaining high-level course themes (some tentative): a Wild West Valley with “villains”/boss encounters to “catch” (detective vibe), a possible music-themed course (currently no clear concept), an oversized casino world (no clear concept), and a comic-book superhero city/skyscraper world.

He adjusts RTYI’s camera D-pad behavior (base velocity vs acceleration curve) after feedback that micro-adjustments feel inconsistent; he wants one control scheme that serves both precise nudges and continuous camera movement, and tests new tuning live.
findings.quote: I am using it as both, and it works for me.

findings.summary: Kaze shares personal context affecting production cadence: he recently moved houses, works full-time at Gears for Breakfast, and repeatedly notes limited free time for long edits/compilations or extra project polish.
findings.quote: I work at Gears for Breakfast now… I just don’t get any free time.

findings.summary: Kaze expresses uncertainty about release timing (hoping for 2024) and highlights how positive reception/virality of recent videos helps momentum; he also notes Twitch multistream is now possible due to TOS changes and sees it as better reach/engagement.
findings.quote: Game of the year 2024… I hope I can release it 2024, I don’t actually know.

badub.summary: Kaze states that Badub has delivered songs for all/most of the areas he is showcasing, and Kaze is already integrating/listening while building levels.

zeina.summary: Zeina confirms Twitch is working again and briefly appears via chat; later Kaze says goodbye to her as she leaves.

findings.summary: Lilaa pushes back on/teases Kaze during the Smash background approach discussion and participates heavily in ideation banter (e.g., suggesting skybox ideas, commenting on shapes/colors).
CatX helps Kaze resolve the background rotation-direction bug by pointing out the underlying logic issue (order-of-operations), which Kaze credits as a key save during the debugging segment.
Keen donates €200, but Kaze misses it for ~30 minutes due to broken alerts; Kaze reacts strongly once he notices and says it meaningfully helps.
ZeroWorld appears in chat during the multistream return; no concrete dev contribution is captured beyond presence.

key_stories.title: Returning to Twitch via multistream and reuniting audiences
key_stories.summary: After months of streaming primarily on YouTube, Kaze returns to Twitch using Restream to broadcast to both platforms simultaneously. He frames it as enabled by Twitch TOS changes and as a way to consolidate chat/engagement while keeping reach high.
key_stories.challenge: Twitch ads and platform constraints pushed him away; he also wants better engagement and discoverability across communities.
key_stories.process: He sets up Restream with on-screen combined chat and tests the workflow live while demoing recent RTYI progress.
key_stories.outcome: He decides the dual setup feels “cozy” and likely becomes his default, noting higher combined viewership and more active chat.
key_stories.key_quote: I really like this. This is a very nice cozy setup for me.

key_stories.title: Finding the right Smash 64 background look without killing performance
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries multiple approaches to recreate Smash 64’s “Board the Platforms” background in 3D. He iterates from distributed transparent squares in space to a more controlled, efficient skysphere method that better matches the original aesthetic.
key_stories.challenge: The iconic look depends on transparency and layering, but N64-era rendering makes heavy overdraw expensive and Fast64 preview transparency is misleading.
key_stories.process: He prototypes square layers, evaluates in-engine vs Fast64, rejects scrolling textures due to overdraw cost, then builds a UV skysphere and plans to draw/cut shapes into it, adding layered rotations.
key_stories.outcome: He reaches a look he considers close to Smash’s vibe and continues into platform blockout for the level’s gameplay pathing.
key_stories.key_quote: We can make a much more impressive effect than this.

key_stories.title: Rotation bug debugging: all layers spin the same way
key_stories.summary: After wiring Fast64 geo rotation nodes and a geo ASM controller, Kaze finds all background layers rotating left despite different intended parameters. The issue turns out to be a small logic/order-of-operations mistake.
key_stories.challenge: Direction parameters appear correct (“one two and nine”), yet the visual result ignores inversion.
key_stories.process: He prints/debugs parameter values, inspects bitwise/logic behavior, and rechecks how the geo ASM applies values to rotation nodes.
key_stories.outcome: He fixes the operator precedence/logic and confirms the layers rotate as intended, calling it reassuring and crediting chat help.
key_stories.key_quote: It was just the order of operations, god damn it.

key_stories.title: Missed €200 donation due to broken alerts
key_stories.summary: Mid-development, Kaze discovers a €200 donation from Keen happened ~30 minutes earlier and he never acknowledged it. He realizes his alerts/notifications are broken, likely due to the new multistream setup.
key_stories.challenge: New streaming setup causes notification failures, risking missed supporter interactions and awkwardness.
key_stories.process: He checks dashboards/Streamlabs/Restream behavior and acknowledges he needs to fix the alerts system going forward.
key_stories.outcome: He thanks Keen and notes the donation “definitely” helps, while committing to revisiting stream reward/alert tooling.
key_stories.key_quote: Someone just donated 200 euros… and I missed it. Holy fuck.

key_stories.title: Camera micro-adjustments vs full camera control
key_stories.summary: A viewer critiques RTYI’s D-pad camera adjustments, saying small taps feel inconsistent because of smoothing/acceleration. Kaze explains he designed it to serve both micro-alignment and continuous camera movement, then experiments with new velocity/acceleration values live.
key_stories.challenge: One input curve may not satisfy both players who want snappy nudges and players who want sustained rotation without menu clutter.
key_stories.process: He explains the existing velocity/acceleration model, tests revised parameters (higher base velocity, lower acceleration), compares to ParallelCam-style behavior, and iterates while compiling.
key_stories.outcome: He settles on a trial configuration that preserves small adjustments but feels usable for “bad players,” leaving open future tuning.
key_stories.key_quote: I don’t like the cluttered options menu. These are all the options you get.
